I'm a bit ignorant on this topic since I don't live in the US, but I recently caught the end of a program which reported that a church political group had successfully campaigned to force the removal of "FCUK" products from being sold in the US. The product was permitted to re-enter the market after its packaging was replaced with the unabbreviated title.
 
 While I don't doubt that the company had intended there would be some controversy (which is always good advertising), I wonder if some representative groups aren't being a little over sensitive?
 
 Given the amount of uncensored violence and sex that is freely presented throughout every corner of our environment, surely this was a pointless exercise? Or is this an important "win" for those that would seek to impose their moral views on the rest of society?

 First of all, the US market is whacked. We censor sex yet glorify massive amounts of violence. We have groups calling cartoons "gay" yet don't say anything about the decay in science that leads to more productive, longer lives. We have religious telemarketers that preach the simple life yet make millions in personal profits that go into offshore accounts. Most, if not all of the groups complaining are not only guilty of some henious crime themselves, but are hypocrites in their daily lives. 
 
 It is likely some republican organization that was offended, nevermind the fact that Cheney told someone to "*** off."
 
 Just gotta make peace with blantant, raging hypocracy.

 Well said.

Yeah, they're very common over here. Very few of them are actually amusing, being along the lines of 'Damn good fcuk' or 'I want a fcuk', though some of the spin offs are good, e.g: '**** fcuk' or 'Cnut: established 1012'
Hypocracy and and FCUK go hand in hand though, they tried to sue a comdedian who had ****: French Correction T-shirts at his show despite at the time having FCUK'd a ton of other people's brands.
